description.narrative: Insatsens övergripande mål är att bidra till en stärkt global förvaltning och förbättrad användning av gemensamma vattenresurser för en rättvis och hållbar framtid, genom att utveckla plattformar, underlätta dialog, generera kunskap, genomföra program, påverkans- och policyarbete och utveckla kapacitet hos relevanta aktörer.

Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI) har ansökt till Sida om finansiering om 120 miljoner SEK för att genomföra det insatsen ”Water Governance for a Just, Prosperous and Sustainable Future” under perioden januari 2021 till december 2023. Insatsen syftar till att stärka en mer programmatisk ansats inom SIWI med förbättrad global vattenstyrning (water governance) som den centrala utgångspunkten, i syfte att bidra till en rättvis och hållbar framtid där de globala hållbarhetsmålen kan uppnås. Insatsen bidrar även till uppfyllelse av SIWI:s strategiska plan 2018-2023, framförallt genom att utveckla plattformar, underlätta dialog, generera kunskap, genomföra projekt och program och bygga kapacitet för förbättrad vattenstyrning globalt. I sitt påverkansarbete rörande vattenstyrning avser SIWI att inverka på utvalda förändringsaktörers beteende, s.k. ’boundary partners’, såsom regeringar, (lokala och nationella), multilaterala organisationer, media och privata sektorn. Programansatsen är uppbyggt av fyra breda programmål som kopplar ihop vattenresurser, vattentjänster, social inkludering och innovation: 1) Bidra till hållbar förvaltning av delade vattenresurser genom förbättrad vattenstyrning, 2) Bidra till motståndskraftiga vattentjänster och infrastruktur genom förbättrad vattenstyrning, 3) Bidra till inkludering av relevanta aktörer genom förbättrad vattenstyrning, samt 4) Bidra till förbättrad och utökad vattenstyrning genom innovationer baserade på kunskap och lärande. Sida bidrar med 120 miljoner SEK till den övergripande programansatsen vilken består av ett flertal projekt. Sidas medel kommer medfinansiera redan pågående eller nya externa projekt, som även finansieras av andra partner, samt stödja SIWI:s interna kapacitetsutveckling.

Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI) has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 120 million to implement the intervention "Water Governance for a Just, Prosperous and Sustainable Future" during the period January 2021 to December 2023. The intervention aims to strengthen a more programmatic approach for SIWI's operations with water governance as the central point of departure, to contribute to an inclusive and sustainable future enabling the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. The intervention will also contribute to the fulfillment of SIWI's strategic plan 2018-2023, primarily by developing platforms, facilitating dialogue, generating knowledge, implementing projects and programmes and building capacity for improved water governance globally. In its water governance advocacy work, SIWI intends to influence the behaviour of selected partners, so-called Boundary partners, such as governments (local and national), multilateral organizations, media and the private sector. The intervention is made up of four broad programme objectives that interlink water resources, water services, social inclusion and innovation: 1) Contribute to sustainable management of shared water resources through improved water governance, 2) Contribute to resilient water services and infrastructure through improved water governance, 3) Contribute to the inclusion of relevant actors through improved water governance, and 4) Contribute to improved and expanded water governance through innovations based on knowledge and learning. Sida will contribute with SEK 120 million to the overarching programmatic approach that is made up of a number of projects. Sida will both co-fund already ongoing or new external projects, also funded by other partners, as well as provide support to SIWI:s internal capacity development.

description.narrative:
Resultaten som presenteras nedan är hämtade ur SIWI:s förenklade narrativa rapport för programstödet: Half-Year Report on Sida Programme Support, 1 January 31 May 2021. SIWI har sammanställt de första 5 månadernas resultat baserat på regelbundna uppföljningar av arbetsplanen för 2021. Resultaten är ofta på process- och aktivitetsnivå.
Programstödet innehåller följande fyra övergripande programmål där en övergripande förändringsteori samt 4 specifika förändringsteorier har utvecklats: - Programme Objective 1: Contribute to Sustainable Management of Shared Water Resources by Improving Water Governance - Programme Objective 2: Contribute to Resilient Water Services and Infrastructures by Improving Water Governance - Programme Objective 3: Contribute to Inclusion of relevant stakeholders by Improving Water Governance - Programme Objective 4: Contribute to Improved and Extended Water Governance by Innovations Based on Knowledge and Learning
Nedan listas exempel som bidrar till strategimål under Strategin för Sveriges globala utvecklingssamarbete inom hållbar miljö, hållbart klimat och hav, samt hållbart nyttjande av naturresurser 2018- 2022 som finansierar SIWI insatsen.
Resultatexempel som levererar mot Strategimål 1 Hav och vatten - vattenresurser (programmål 1 och 2)
In relation to governments/public agencies implementing improved policies for the sustainable management of shared water resources: - SIWI has contributed to the preparation of the Climate Resilient Water Resources Management Plan for Nigeria that was completed in Q1 2021. - SIWI has supported the Chu and Talas basin stakeholders in achieving several results, for example: A draft Joint Action Programme for Chu and Talas River Basins, draft National Action Plan of Kazakhstan for Chu and Talas River Basins; draft National Action Plan of Kyrgyzstan for Chu and Talas River Basins; completed draft Project Identification of the GEF Chu-Talas SAP Implementation project; and formalized agreement on coordinated monitoring and data exchange in the two basins.
Key results related to multilateral organisations implementing initiatives and projects establishing mechanisms for coordinated governance of shared water resources: - A discussion paper Water productivity, the yield gap and nutrition the case of Ethiopia, was launched in April 2021, building upon SIWIs engagement in The Global Framework on Water Scarcity in Agriculture (WASAG). The paper was prepared by SIWI, SLU and FAO. The paper was accompanied by a policy brief Nutrition and the Perfect Storm of Water and blog-post on Good water management helps smallholders improve their diets and incomes.
For transboundary water-related boundary partners: - SIWI achieved increased awareness on gender and youth in water diplomacy and contributed to the capacitation of journalists and national decision-makers by organising a virtual session on elevating youth participation in water diplomacy processes. The two main objectives of the session was to; strengthen the future youth water leaders community, and to encourage actors such as Policy makers, Ministers of Foreign Affairs and Water ministers involved in water diplomacy dialogues to increase youth participation in their discussions and decision-making processes.
SIWI facilitated dialogue and strengthened capacities on resilient water services and infrastructure of government actors in Central Asia and in Somalia by: - co-organizing a virtual dialogue meeting in an ongoing initiative named "Water as a Driver of Sustainable Economic Recovery for Central Asia including Afghanistan". Presentations from the participating governments reflect the difficulties of discussing investment issues pertinent to transboundary water cooperation at the regional scale. However, numerous examples of cooperation progressing at a bilateral or sub-basin scale have been presented and may provide greater opportunities for progress. - Establishing a close working relationship with the Federal Republic of Somalia's Office of the President's Transboundary Water Diplomatic Committee (TWDC) with which SIWI is organising a series of capacity building and experience exchange opportunities for key actors engaged in transboundary water decision making in Somalia
Resultatexempel som levererar mot Strategimål 2 Hav och Vatten - föroreningar (programmål 1)
Around 40 participants from more than 20 countries participated in the interactive workshop organised by the the Source-to-Sea (S2S) Platform, the Swedish Agency for Marine and Water Management (SwAM) and SIWI in March 2021, which focused on the challenges and opportunities of implementing the Source-to-Sea approach.
SIWI also contributed to research institutes providing research on challenges and solutions related to sustainable management of shared water resources through a Special Issue on Source-to-Sea Management launched in the journal Water International. Delays in implementation in the S2S pilot countries were experienced due to Covid-19 in Vietnam and due to political tension in Ethiopia.
Resultatexempel som levererar mot Strategimål 2 Klimat - sårbarhet (programmål 2)
In Bolivia SIWI has supported in creating a taskforce for assessing Climate and Environmental Risks for its integration in WASH Bottleneck Analysis - WASHBAT. The taskforce is taking off as a network of NGOs, projects and universities with the aim of sharing Knowledge further than the original scope of informing the WASHBAT.
In Iraq a risk-informed WASHBAT was completed at sub-national level for two water scarcity affected Governorates in the South-West of Iraq. This was the first time a climate and water scarcity risk assessment has been undertaken as a pre-step for a WASHBAT and ensured that the WASH enabling environment and governance issues discussed at the WASHBAT workshop were discussed with the additional water scarcity and climate change lens.
SIWI also co-authored a policy brief with SEI entitled A Just Transition for Climate Change Adaptation: Towards Just Resilience and Security in a Globalizing World.
Resultatexempel som levererar mot tematiska perspektiv (programmål 1 och 3)
Jämställdhet:
SIWI supported the collaboration of Women in Water Diplomacy Network in the Nile collaborated with the Finnish Ministry of Foreign Affair's Centre for Peace Mediation (CPM) to engage in an experience exchange session with the Finnish Water Diplomacy Network and the Finnish members of the Nordic Women Mediator Network. The meeting led to experience exchange around the intersect of water diplomacy, gender equality, and women's leadership in decision-making with a focus on fragile or conflict sensitive regions. The session provided the Women in Water Diplomacy in the Nile Network with an opportunity to expand their professional networks, while also hearing about lessons learnt from water diplomats and mediators in other regions. Additionally, it has increased the awareness and knowledge of Finnish ambassadors, experts and diplomats of the role of Water and Peace as well as the contributions of water diplomacy to peace and security processes and elevated the perspectives of the participating members of the Women in Water Diplomacy Network in the Nile.
Rättighetsperspektivet:
The efforts from SIWI along with its partners by producing different knowledge products and hosting several learning events, have contributed to influencing stakeholders to strengthen the linkages between water and open government reforms, mobilize actions that help realize the human right to water and sanitation and improve water governance. These efforts have led to influencing partners like Open Government Partnership (OGP), who approached SIWI to provide technical support to the Sekondi Takoradi Metropolitan Assembly (STMA)-Ghana towards improving the municipalitys implementation workplan for their OGP commitment on Citizen Engagement in the Delivery of Public Sanitation Services. A set of online sessions were conducted with the STMA stakeholders that helped the municipality in identifying key water and sanitation stakeholder, improving the stakeholder engagement, and in problem-identification and strengthening their workplan. This also led to the publication of a toolkit, the Water and Open Government: A Step-by-Step City Guide (May 2021), to support cities develop water and open government reforms.
Resultatexempel kopplade till interna förbättringsarbetet (programmål 4)
Audit - A positive result has been that SIWI has received fewer audit remarks and has overall improved the quality of project applications and funding agreements, including the documentation thereof. SIWI acknowledges that although the organization has received fewer audit remarks, audit recommendations related to the statutory audit continues to be highlighted. SIWI is therefore continuously working on improving routines related to financial follow-ups.
Financial systems - Procuring and implementing the new accounting software has been highlighted as an important component to secure adequate financial control. The process has been initiated under the first half of 2021 and a vendor for a new software has been procured, including training and implementation support. A new staff member leading the implementation and roll out from SIWIs side has been contracted. Work will continue during Q2-Q4.
Results management - As a continuous effort to improve Results Reporting a specific function in SIWIlization has been finalized under the first half of 2021. Result reporting function in Siwilization allows linking results to cross cutting issues, the strategic and program objectives. Training has been provided across the organization to ensure proper utilization of this functionality.
Governance - SIWI is undertaking a review of its governance structure. The current legal entity set up served the organisation's interest well when it was established. However, today it represents an obstacle. A review of the current structure is needed for two main reasons. The activities of the Foundation group would benefit from a structure where a clearer division is made between the development cooperation-funded projects and the World Water Week / the Prizes. Secondly, and most important, a very tiny equity base in the SIWI foundation (being in charge of all operations in the foundation group) makes the entire set up very vulnerable to economic deficits in the SIWI foundation, risking the very existence of SIWI.
